pages.title: Title
pages.altText: Picture showing the transparent upper torso of a human with the bones visible

pageData.text: Blood consists of cells and cell fragments, collectively known as the <button class='glossary-text'>formed elements</button>, surrounded by a fluid called <button class='glossary-text'>plasma</button>. An elaborate network of vessels carries blood to and from the heart, lungs, and other parts of the body. In this investigation, the student will conduct tests to evaluate the <button class='glossary-text'>erythrocyte</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>hemoglobin</button> content of blood, measure bleeding time, and identify different types of blood vessels.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 10 minutes
 Activity 1: Hematocrit Test – 40 minutes
 Activity 2: Copper Sulfate Test – 5 minutes
 Activity 3: Bleeding Time Test – 15 minutes
 Activity 4: Blood Vessels – 5 minutes

pageData.subTitle: Note for instructors:
pageData.text: This investigation involves the student providing photos and test values from blood tests to you as part of the assessment. This is confidential medical information that should not be stored or shared with your health services group or the rest of the class.

pageData.subTitle: Note for students:
pageData.text: The blood tests performed in this investigation are for educational purposes and should not be used for diagnosis of medical conditions. If your results seem unusual, seek advice from a medical professional.

text: Adhesive bandages (at least 3)
Timer or cell phone with a timer function
Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking photos
Clean absorbent material, such as a cotton ball, gauze pad, paper towel, or tissue
Household bleach diluted 1:10 with tap water
Hard-sided disposable container (for disposal of sharp objects)

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Blood and Blood Vessels: Hematocrit

text: Describe the composition of blood and the normal values of blood composition.
Recall the different types of blood cells, and describe their characteristics.
Determine the <button class='glossary-text'>hematocrit</button> value of a blood sample.
Determine the <button class='glossary-text'>hemoglobin</button> content of a blood sample.
Evaluate blood clotting.
Describe the general structure of a blood vessel, and differentiate among types of blood vessels.

pageData.text: Adult non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL) is the seventh most common cancer in U.S. adults. Approximately 82,000 people were diagnosed in the U.S. with NHL in 2020. NHL starts in <button class='glossary-text'>lymphocytes</button> (white blood cells) and becomes malignant, spreading from the lymphatic system to other parts of the body. “Non-Hodgkin’s” refers to the absence of Reed-Sternberg cells, also called Hodgkin cells, in the cancerous tissue. Reed-Sternberg cells are large, abnormal lymphocytes that often have more than one nucleus and are found in patients diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma.

There are many different types of NHL, but they are generally divided into two major groups: indolent and aggressive. Indolent NHL is slow-moving, usually the patient experiences very few symptoms. Aggressive NHL grows quickly and causes symptoms that include painful lymph nodes, pain in the chest, abdomen, or bones, and a feeling of fullness even though no food has been consumed. NHL is a treatable disease and many patients have been cured, particularly with aggressive NHL. It is estimated that the stage IV NHL 5-year survival rate is about 63%.  Continued research and advancements in treatments hope to improve the survival rate for all patients.

pageData.desc: A blood smear micrograph showing a lymphoma cell among many red blood cells.
pageData.altText: A blood smear micrograph showing a lymphoma cell among many red blood cells.

pageData.text: Blood has two main components: a straw-colored fluid called and the , which are composed of cells and cell fragments. When a sample of whole blood is separated, typically by centrifugation, these components become visible (see Figure 1). On average, plasma makes up 55% of the volume of whole blood.

pageData.subTitle: Constituents of Plasma
pageData.text:
Plasma is approximately 90% water. Dissolved in the plasma are:
  • The respiratory gases oxygen (O2) and carbon dioxide (CO2)
  • Proteins
    • , the most abundant plasma protein and the most important plasma constituent for maintaining osmotic pressure
    • , some of which transport lipids, certain vitamins, and ions while others participate in the immune response
    • , which can come out of solution when a blood vessel is injured and form a mesh of fibrin, an essential component of a blood clot
  • Nitrogenous waste products, such as urea, uric acid, and creatinine
  • Electrolytes—such as sodium, potassium, chloride, and bicarbonate—which help maintain blood pH and contribute to osmotic pressure
  • Nutrients absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract
  • , chemical messengers of the endocrine system

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram of a whole blood sample showing the relative contribution of the formed elements and plasma

pageData.subTitle: Formed Elements of Blood
pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>formed elements</button> (see Figure 2) are <button class='glossary-text'>erythrocytes</button> (red blood cells, or RBCs); <button class='glossary-text'>leukocytes</button> (white blood cells, or WBCs), which include <button class='glossary-text'>monocytes</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>eosinophils</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>lymphocytes</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>neutrophils</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>basophils</button>; and <button class='glossary-text'>thrombocytes</button> (platelets).

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Labeled drawings of the formed elements of blood

pageData.text: Erythrocytes are the most abundant of the formed elements, making up roughly 45% of whole blood. The percentage of whole blood consisting of erythrocytes is known as the (see ). Normal hematocrit values vary somewhat by sex. Hematocrit values for healthy adults are approximately 40.7%-50.3% for males and 36.1%-44.3% for females. In Activity 1 of this investigation, you will determine the hematocrit value of a sample of your blood.

Figure 3 shows a stained human blood smear. Notice that the overwhelming majority of cells are erythrocytes; only two leukocytes are visible. Each erythrocyte is a biconcave disc—a flattened cell with an indentation in the center, approximately 7.5 μm in diameter. Mature erythrocytes lack a nucleus and most organelles. They contain mainly , a protein that binds O2 and CO2 and assists in their transport through the bloodstream.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: A human blood smear viewed through a microscope

pageData.question: The majority of the cells in this micrograph are ___________ .

options.text: erythrocytes
leukocytes
neutrophils
eosinophils
hemoglobin

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The overwhelming majority of cells are erythrocytes (red blood cells); only two leukocytes are visible (white blood cells). Each erythrocyte is a biconcave disc, a flattened cell with an indentation in the center, approximately 7.5 μm in diameter.

imageData.altText: Figure 3: A human blood smear viewed through a microscope

pageData.question: Although they make up less than half the total volume of whole blood, erythrocytes make up the majority of what portion of whole blood?

options.text: formed elements
buffy coat
plasma
leukocytes
serum

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The formed elements of blood consist of cells and cell fragments. Most formed elements are erythrocytes. Only a small fraction of formed elements is made up of leukocytes and thrombocytes.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The formed elements are erythrocytes; leukocytes, which include monocytes, eosinophils, lymphocytes, neutrophils, and basophils; and thrombocytes. Erythrocytes are the most abundant of the formed elements, making up roughly 45% of whole blood. The percentage of whole blood consisting of erythrocytes for a particular individual is known as the hematocrit. Although 45% is the average, normal hematocrit values vary somewhat by sex. Hematocrit values for healthy adults are approximately 40.7%–50.3% for males and 36.1%–44.3% for females.

img.alt: Figure 2: Labeled drawings of the formed elements of blood

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The formed elements are erythrocytes; leukocytes, which include monocytes, eosinophils, lymphocytes, neutrophils, and basophils; and thrombocytes. Erythrocytes are the most abundant of the formed elements, making up roughly 45% of whole blood. The percentage of whole blood consisting of erythrocytes for a particular individual is known as the hematocrit. Although 45% is the average, normal hematocrit values vary somewhat by sex. Hematocrit values for healthy adults are approximately 40.7%–50.3% for males and 36.1%–44.3% for females.

img.alt: Figure 2: Labeled drawings of the formed elements of blood

pageData.text: The structure of includes iron. If an individual does not have enough iron in their diet for hemoglobin synthesis, their are unable to transport sufficient amounts of oxygen, leading to a condition called . Due to an inability to synthesize hemoglobin, blood droplets from individuals with iron-deficiency anemia are less dense than those from individuals with normal hemoglobin levels. In Activity 2 of this investigation, you will perform a in which a drop of blood is added to a copper sulfate solution. If the blood hemoglobin content is normal, the drop of blood will sink to the bottom of the tube within 15 seconds. If the individual has iron-deficiency anemia, the drop of blood will stop sinking around the middle of the tube or even start to float toward the top. This test is useful for determining if an individual should donate blood.

are less plentiful than erythrocytes, contributing less than 1% of total blood volume. In a separated whole blood sample, the leukocytes and together make up a thin layer between the and erythrocytes called the (see ). Leukocytes possess nuclei and other cellular organelles. There are several types of leukocytes, which vary widely in size, appearance, and function (see ).

• are the most abundant of the leukocytes overall, constituting between 50% and 70% of the total leukocyte count. The primary function of neutrophils is to protect the body from bacterial infection.
  • make up 2%–4% of leukocytes. They function mainly in protecting the body from parasitic worms but also play an important role in the allergic response.
  • are the rarest type of leukocyte, constituting only 0.5%–1% of leukocytes. They contain histamine, an important chemical in the inflammatory response.
  • represent around 25% of the leukocyte population and play important roles in the immune response.
  • make up 3%–8% of leukocytes. They can leave the bloodstream and migrate into the tissues, where they differentiate into macrophages—large, phagocytic cells that protect the body from infectious microbes.

<button class='glossary-text'>Thrombocytes</button> (see <button class='resource-text'>Figure 2</button>) are tiny cell fragments that, along with fibrin from <button class='glossary-text'>plasma</button>, help stop bleeding when a blood vessel is injured. The cells that give rise to thrombocytes are known as megakaryocytes. These enormous cells do not circulate in the bloodstream; rather, they reside in the bone marrow and form numerous buds that break off and become thrombocytes.

Damage to a blood vessel wall initiates a series of activities, collectively known as , to stop the bleeding. The first step is vascular spasm, in which smooth muscle in the vessel wall constricts, reducing the amount of blood flow in the affected area. Next, a thrombocyte plug (platelet plug) forms, which temporarily seals the damaged area of the blood vessel wall. Finally, the thrombocyte plug is reinforced with a mesh of fibrin protein. Hemostasis is very rapid; a finger stick such as the one you will perform in Activity 3 typically stops bleeding in between 1 and 9 minutes. Once hemostasis is complete, the blood clot retracts and pulls the damaged edges of the blood vessel closer together to promote the healing process.

The relative abundance of plasma vs. <button class='glossary-text'>formed elements</button> and of the different types of formed elements in a blood sample can provide information about an individual’s health. For instance, a low proportion of plasma relative to formed elements may indicate dehydration. A low thrombocyte count, known as thrombocytopenia, results in spontaneous bleeding.

pageData.question: Which of the following is NOT a leukocyte?

options.text: thrombocyte
lymphocyte
monocyte
neutrophil
basophil

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Thrombocytes, also known as platelets, are cell fragments that combine with fibrin in the plasma to create blood clots at injury sites. They are not considered leukocytes, or white blood cells, which perform various immune responses.

pageData.question: Leukocytes make up a very small percentage of whole blood, yet they play a vital role in maintaining homeostasis. Which of the following best describes the overall function of leukocytes in the body?

options.text: They are responsible for immune responses.
They are responsible for closing wounds.
They are responsible for allergies to the environment.
They are responsible for differentiating stem cells.
They are responsible for supporting erythrocytes.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The overall function of leukocytes is to protect the body via immune responses.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Leukocytes are less plentiful than erythrocytes, contributing less than 1% of total blood volume. There are several types of leukocytes, which vary widely in size, appearance, and function.

tableData.text: produce histamine involved in inflammatory responses
protect against parasitic worms; involved in allergic responses
mature into macrophages that protect against infectious microbes

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Leukocytes are less plentiful than erythrocytes, contributing less than 1% of total blood volume. There are several types of leukocytes, which vary widely in size, appearance, and function.

tableData.text: produce histamine involved in inflammatory responses

pageData.subTitle: Cardiovascular Pathways
pageData.text: There are two distinct cardiovascular pathways: the <button class='glossary-text'>pulmonary circulation</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>systemic circulation</button>. Figure 4 is a simplified diagram showing representative vessels of both pathways in relation to the heart. Together, these two pathways carry blood throughout the body while maintaining separation of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. The pulmonary circulation carries deoxygenated blood away from the heart through the <button class='glossary-text'>capillaries</button> in the lungs and then returns oxygenated blood to the heart. The systemic circulation is responsible for providing this oxygen-rich blood to the rest of the body and returning the blood to the heart so the blood can enter the pulmonary circulation.

<button class='glossary-text'>Arteries</button> are blood vessels that convey blood away from the heart. In the pulmonary circulation, the right and left pulmonary arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs (Figure 4). In the systemic circulation, arteries carry oxygenated blood. The <button class='glossary-text'>aorta</button> is the largest artery, receiving the systemic output of the heart. The aorta branches into smaller arteries serving different parts of the body. For example, the hepatic artery carries blood to the liver, the mesenteric arteries supply much of the gastrointestinal tract, and the right and left renal arteries serve the kidneys.

Capillaries are the smallest blood vessels with the thinnest walls. Capillary beds—networks of capillaries—generally lie between the smallest arteries and the smallest . They are the sites of , a process in which respiratory gases as well as nutrients, metabolic wastes, and other molecules are exchanged between the blood and the tissues.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Simplified diagram of the cardiovascular pathways

pageData.text: Veins are blood vessels that convey blood toward the heart. In the pulmonary circulation, the pulmonary veins carry oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart (see Figure 4). In the systemic circulation, veins carry deoxygenated blood. For example, the renal veins receive blood leaving the kidneys and the hepatic veins carry blood from the liver. Venous blood in the systemic circulation converges in a . There are two venae cavae in humans, and they are the largest veins of the body. The inferior vena cava receives blood returning to the heart from the lower body, and the superior vena cava receives blood from the upper body. Both venae cavae convey blood into the heart.

pageData.subTitle: Blood Vessel Structure
pageData.text: Blood vessels vary greatly in structure. For example, arteries and <button class='glossary-text'>veins</button> of comparable diameter are easy to distinguish when viewed in cross section (see Figure 5). Arteries tend to have a smaller <button class='glossary-text'>lumen</button> (interior space) and thicker walls, with a high proportion of smooth muscle and/or elastic fibers. In Activity 4, you will distinguish between an <button class='glossary-text'>artery</button> and vein of comparable diameter.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Cross-sectional view of a vein and an artery

pageData.question: Which of the following carries blood toward the heart?

options.text: veins
capillaries
elastic fibers
lumen
arteries

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Veins are blood vessels that convey blood toward the heart. In pulmonary circulation, the pulmonary veins carry oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the function of arteries and veins in pulmonary circulation?

options.text: Arteries carry oxygen-poor blood and veins carry oxygen-rich blood.
Arteries carry blood to the heart and veins carry blood away from the heart.
Arteries carry oxygen-rich blood and veins carry oxygen-poor blood.
Arteries carry blood to the body and veins carry blood to the lungs.
Arteries carry blood to the lungs and veins carry blood to the body.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The pulmonary circulation carries oxygen-poor (deoxygenated) blood away from the heart via the pulmonary artery, through the capillaries in the lungs, and then returns oxygen-rich (oxygenated) blood to the heart via the pulmonary vein.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Arteries are blood vessels that convey blood away from the heart. Veins are blood vessels that convey blood toward the heart. Capillaries are the smallest blood vessels with the thinnest walls. Capillary beds, networks of capillaries, generally lie between the smallest arteries and the smallest veins. These blood vessels facilitate two distinct cardiovascular pathways: pulmonary circulation and systemic circulation.

img.alt: Figure 4: Simplified diagram of the cardiovascular pathways

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Together, these two pathways carry blood throughout the body while maintaining separation of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. Pulmonary circulation carries deoxygenated blood away from the heart through the capillaries in the lungs and then returns oxygenated blood to the heart. Systemic circulation is responsible for providing this oxygen-rich blood to the rest of the body and returning the blood to the heart so the blood can enter the pulmonary circulation.

img.alt: Figure 4: Simplified diagram of the cardiovascular pathways

pageData.text: There are distinct subcategories within each of the three major blood vessel types. To understand the different classifications of blood vessels, it is necessary to be familiar with their structural similarities. Because of their large size, the venae cavae are good examples for the examination of general blood vessel structure. As shown in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 6</button>, there are three main layers of a blood vessel wall:

1. The (or tunica interna) is the innermost layer of the vessel wall, located adjacent to the . The tunica intima consists of a (a single layer of flattened cells) called the , which lines the lumen. Adjacent to the endothelium is the , which helps the endothelium bind to the next layer. Many vessels have a layer of elastic fibers called the (or internal elastic lamina) at the outer boundary of the tunica intima.

1. The is the middle layer of the vessel wall. The tunica media is substantially thicker in arteries compared to . It is composed of smooth muscle and connective tissue. In , the tunica media contains a generous amount of elastic fibers. Elastic fibers help the larger arteries expand to accommodate pressure from blood being forced from the heart and then recoil to their original dimensions. In other arteries, the smooth muscle is predominant. The smooth muscle is important in — the narrowing of the lumen of the when the muscle contracts. Vasoconstriction is important for regulating blood pressure in the arteries, reducing blood loss following an injury, and adjusting body temperature. , the opposite of vasoconstriction, occurs when the smooth muscle relaxes, increasing the lumen diameter. In larger arteries (but not veins), there may be an additional distinct layer of elastic fibers, called the (or external elastic lamina), located at the outer boundary of the tunica media.

1. The (or tunica adventitia) is the outermost layer of a blood vessel wall. It is composed mainly of connective tissue, although the largest veins may also have smooth muscle tissue in this layer. Some vessels may have a nerve supply, the , and/or smaller blood vessels, , in this layer. The nerves allow the nervous system to control vasoconstriction and . The blood vessels are necessary because the walls of large vessels are too thick for molecules, such as respiratory gases and nutrients, to diffuse from the blood inside the large vessels to the cells in the outer layers of the vessels.

pageData.subTitle: Blood Vessel Categories
pageData.text: There are different categories of arteries based on relative diameter and the makeup of their walls (see Figure 6). Recall that the <button class='glossary-text'>aorta</button> is the largest <button class='glossary-text'>artery</button> of the body. With each heartbeat, a wave of blood under high pressure surges into the <button class='glossary-text'>lumen</button> of the aorta. For this reason, the walls of the aorta need to be able to repeatedly expand and then recoil to their original dimensions. Other large arteries are still relatively close to the heart and share this need for elasticity. Such large arteries, which have a generous proportion of elastic fibers in their walls, are called <button class='glossary-text'>elastic arteries</button>. Somewhat smaller arteries, with less elastic fibers and a higher proportion of smooth muscle in their walls, are known as <button class='glossary-text'>muscular arteries</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Arterioles</button> are the smallest arteries. They convey blood into <button class='glossary-text'>capillaries</button>.

Just as there are different sizes of arteries, there are also different sizes of <button class='glossary-text'>veins</button> (see Figure 6). The smallest veins are the <button class='glossary-text'>venules</button>, which receive blood from capillary beds.Venules converge into small veins, which come together at medium-size veins. Eventually, blood returning from the <button class='glossary-text'>systemic circulation</button> to the heart enters one of the two large venae cavae. Some medium-size and large veins, especially in the limbs, have one-way valves that prevent the backflow of blood.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: Diagram of the different types of arteries, veins, and capillaries

pageData.text: There are even different types of <button class='glossary-text'>capillaries</button> (see <button class='resource-text'>Figure 6</button>). <button class='glossary-text'>Continuous capillaries</button> are the most common type to form capillary beds between <button class='glossary-text'>arterioles</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>venules</button>. They are abundant in the dermis of the skin, skeletal muscles, and most connective tissues. These are also the capillaries that surround the <button class='glossary-text'>alveoli</button> (air sacs) of the lungs. The wall of a continuous capillary typically consists of a single layer of endothelial cells with a <button class='glossary-text'>basement membrane</button>. In other words, the capillary wall consists only of <button class='glossary-text'>tunica intima</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Fenestrated capillaries</button> are found in the small intestine, kidneys, and endocrine glands such as the pancreas, which all are organs where a great deal of molecular exchange occurs between blood and tissues. These capillaries are so named because the abundant pores (fenestrae or fenestrations) in their walls make them highly permeable to molecules of larger size than the respiratory gases.

pageData.question: Which of the following describes categories of blood vessels in order from largest to smallest?

options.text: elastic artery, muscular artery, arteriole, capillary
muscular artery, elastic artery, arteriole, capillary
capillary, arteriole, elastic artery, muscular artery
arteriole, elastic artery, muscular artery, capillary
arteriole, capillary, muscular artery, elastic artery

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The largest arteries are elastic arteries. Muscular arteries are the next largest; they feed into smaller arterioles which feed into capillaries.

pageData.question: Blood vessels are categorized by which of the following sets of characteristics?

options.text: wall composition and relative size
wall thickness and number of layers
vessel diameter only
relative size and the presence of valves
the number of vessels in the body and relative location

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: There are different categories of blood vessels based on relative diameter and the makeup of their walls.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: There are different categories of blood vessels based on relative diameter and the makeup of their walls. The largest arteries, including the aorta, are called elastic arteries because their walls contain a large proportion of elastic fibers to help them expand and recoil with each pump of blood from the heart. Somewhat smaller arteries, with less elastic fibers and a higher proportion of smooth muscle in their walls, are known as muscular arteries. Arterioles are the smallest arteries. They convey blood into capillaries.

img.alt: Figure 6: Diagram of the different types of arteries, veins, and capillaries

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The largest veins are the venae cavae. Medium-size and large veins, especially in the limbs, have one-way valves that prevent the backflow of blood. The smallest veins are the venules, which receive blood from capillary beds.

img.alt: Figure 6: Diagram of the different types of arteries, veins, and capillaries

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. To prepare, watch the blood smear demonstration video. In Activity 1, you will collect a blood sample in a hematocrit tube and calculate the hematocrit value. In Activity 2, you will collect a blood sample into a copper sulfate solution and conduct a copper sulfate test for hemoglobin. In Activity 3, you will stick your finger to draw blood and then conduct a bleeding time test. In Activity 4, you will distinguish between blood vessels in a micrograph.

In Activity 1, you will collect a blood sample in a hematocrit tube and calculate the hematocrit value. In Activity 2, you will collect a blood sample into a copper sulfate solution and conduct a copper sulfate test for hemoglobin. In Activity 3, you will stick your finger to draw blood and then conduct a bleeding time test. In Activity 4, you will distinguish between blood vessels in a micrograph.

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: This procedure involves obtaining a small sample of your blood by sticking a finger with a sterile lancet. If you are unable to perform this activity, alert the course instructor. Use only your own blood for this investigation. If you have previously experienced faintness or dizziness at the sight of blood, it is recommended that another person be present during the finger stick. Make sure you are in a seated, comfortable position with an armrest to secure your body should any dizziness occur.

Copper sulfate causes skin and eye irritation. In case of contact with eyes, rinse immediately with copious water and seek medical advice/attention. If skin contact occurs, wash with plenty of soap and water, and seek medical advice/attention. Remove contaminated clothing and wash before reuse. If swallowed, do not induce vomiting; seek medical advice immediately.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: As a best practice, all human blood should always be treated as if it may contain potentially infectious microbes. After this investigation, all materials that have come into contact with your blood should be soaked in a 10% bleach solution for an hour before disposal.
pageData.altText: health hazard symbol

pageData.text: Household bleach can damage eyes and skin, and it should not be ingested. Use it only in a well-ventilated area, such as a room with an open window or a bathroom with a ventilation fan. Always wear PPE (goggles, an apron, and gloves) when handling bleach. If bleach gets into your eyes, rinse them thoroughly with water for several minutes. If wearing contact lenses, remove them if practical to do so and then continue rinsing. If bleach contacts your skin, wash thoroughly with soap and water. If bleach contacts your clothing, remove the clothing and wash it before wearing it again. If ingested, do not induce vomiting. Rinse your mouth thoroughly with water, and seek medical attention immediately.
pageData.altText: warning symbol, corrosion symbol

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the difference between erythrocytes from anemic individuals and erythrocytes from healthy individuals?

options.text: Erythrocytes from anemic individuals are lighter due to a lack of iron.
Erythrocytes from anemic individuals are heavier due to excess copper.
Erythrocytes from anemic individuals are crescent shaped due to a mutation.

assestmentData.question: Plasma donation is a common source of extra income for many people, especially college students. During each pre-donation screening, an individual’s hematocrit is evaluated. Imagine a hematocrit tube filled with a blood sample has a total volume of 5 cm, of which 2 cm is made up of blood cells. What is the hematocrit value of the sample?
Which of the following sets of blood components work together to form blood clots after an injury?

options.text: fibrin and platelets
platelets, lymphocytes, and erythrocytes
erythrocytes and neutrophils
plasma and basophils
monocytes and lymphocytes

assestmentData.question: Which of these is the hollow, blood-filled space within a blood vessel?

options.text: lumen
tunica
systole
diastole
thrombin

assestmentData.question: A vein and an artery from the same part of the body are each prepared into cross sections and placed on a microscope slide for observation. Which of the following best describes how to differentiate between these two types of blood vessels?

options.text: The artery will have thicker walls than the vein.
The artery will have thinner walls than the vein.
The artery will have more tissue layers in its walls than the vein.
The artery will have fewer tissue layers in its walls than the vein.
The artery will be lined with cilia while the vein will be smooth.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following describes the purpose of the copper sulfate solution provided in your lab kit for this investigation?

options.text: to determine the hemoglobin content of a blood sample
to determine the hematocrit value of a blood sample
to determine the blood pressure of a test subject
to stain the blood vessels on a prepared microscope slide
to disinfect blood-contaminated materials during cleanup

assestmentData.question: After completing this investigation, all materials that have come into contact with your blood should be soaked in a 10% bleach solution for an hour before disposal. Which of the following best explains the reasoning behind this disposal procedure?

options.text: Human blood should always be treated as if it contains potentially infectious microbes.
Human blood always contains viruses that can spread if not properly disinfected.
Human blood will stain the materials if not treated with bleach before washing.
Human blood should always be treated as if it contains Rh factor.
Human blood is toxic if ingested and should be neutralized before disposal.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the proper method for disposing of the sharp items (hematocrit tubes and safety lancets) from this investigation upon completing the activities?

options.text: Place the items in a hard-sided container, then place the container in the household garbage.
Place the items directly in the household garbage.
Place the items in a resealable plastic bag, then place the bag in the household garbage.
Place the items in a hard-sided container, then place the container in a special receptacle on your school’s campus.
Place the items directly in a recycling bin.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.

Review all the instructions carefully before you begin. Your blood must be collected quickly to avoid clotting. Before performing the test in Activity 1, view the Obtaining a Blood Sample for Hematocrit video.

pageData.subTitle: Obtaining a Blood Sample for Hematocrit

pageData.text: Arrange all materials so they are within easy reach.
In Activity 1, you will collect a sample of your own blood in a <button class='glossary-text'>hematocrit</button> tube and perform a test for hematocrit.

Massage the finger you will stick to maximize blood flow. Any finger may be used; the middle and ring fingers are the most popular choices because they are generally less sensitive than the thumb and pinkie.
Wipe your fingertip with an alcohol prep (alcohol swab). Wait several seconds for the alcohol to evaporate.
Remove the cap from the safety lancet.

Touch the lancet to the side of your finger, roughly a quarter of an inch from the fingertip. Press firmly so the spring-loaded lancet is discharged and the skin is punctured. Then set the lancet aside. Do not reuse the lancet.
Squeeze a drop of blood from the fingertip and wipe it away with a cotton ball, paper towel, or other clean absorbent material. Gently squeeze your finger again to obtain a second drop of blood.

Take a <button class='glossary-text'>hematocrit</button> tube, and put the end without the ring against the droplet of blood at a 45° angle. The blood will be pulled into the tube. The tube must fill at least halfway to allow you to estimate your hematocrit. A tube filled almost to the ring at the top is best.

If some blood goes into the hematocrit tube and an air bubble forms, remove the hematocrit tube and use a new tube. The air bubble will not allow for correct separation.If you are unable to fill the tube at least halfway before you stop bleeding, repeat the finger stick with a new lancet and try again with a different tube.

When the hematocrit tube is almost full, put a finger on the top end of the tube (the end with the ring). Remove the tube while keeping the top end sealed with your finger. Carefully push a small piece of modeling clay into the open end of the tube to form a plug. Then push the plugged end into a larger piece of clay to hold the tube upright as the blood sample separates.
Cover your fingertip with an adhesive bandage.

Let the hematocrit tube sit undisturbed for at least 30 minutes. You should see the blood separate into <button class='glossary-text'>formed elements</button> (mostly <button class='glossary-text'>erythrocytes</button>) at the bottom of the tube and clear, straw-colored <button class='glossary-text'>plasma</button> at the top of the tube. Take a photo.
Carefully lift the hematocrit tube out of the large piece of clay, leaving the small clay plug in the bottom of the tube. Hold the hematocrit tube on a flat surface.

Use the ruler to measure to the nearest tenth of a centimeter how far the blood entered the tube, from the bottom of the tube to the top of the plasma fraction. Record this number in the “Total Volume” column in Data Table 1.
Measure the distance from the bottom to the top of the formed elements fraction of blood, and record this in the “Formed Elements” column in Data Table 1.
Calculate the hematocrit value, and enter it in Data Table 1. Use the following formula:hematocrit value = (formed elements/ total volume) x 100%
In Activity 2, you will collect a second sample of your own blood to conduct a <button class='glossary-text'>copper sulfate test</button> for <button class='glossary-text'>hemoglobin</button>.
Fill the test tube approximately three-quarters full of copper sulfate solution.
Massage the finger you will stick to maximize blood flow. Do not choose the same finger used for Activity 1.
Wipe your fingertip with an alcohol prep. Wait several seconds for the alcohol to evaporate.
Remove the cap from the safety lancet.

Touch the lancet to the side of your finger, roughly a quarter of an inch from the fingertip. Press firmly so the spring-loaded lancet is discharged and the skin is punctured. Then set the lancet aside. <span class='bodyFontBold'>Do not reuse the lancet.</span.>
Squeeze a drop of blood from your fingertip, and wipe it away with a cotton ball, paper towel, or other clean absorbent material. Gently squeeze your finger again to obtain a second drop of blood.
Let the blood drop into the copper sulfate solution. Start the timer immediately.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Observe the drop, and note its location in the tube in Data Table 2 at 0, 15 and 60 seconds after its initial deposition in the copper sulfate solution. Take a photo at the 60-second mark.
Cover your fingertip with an adhesive bandage.
In Activity 3, you will perform a fresh finger stick and record the time it takes for bleeding to stop.

pages.title: Bleeding Time Test
pages.pageTitle:
A
A Bleeding Time Test (07 steps)

pageData.text: Massage the finger you will stick to maximize blood flow. Do not choose the same fingers used for Activities 1 and 2.
Wipe your fingertip with an alcohol prep. Wait several seconds for the alcohol to evaporate.
Remove the cap from the safety lancet.

Touch the lancet to the side of your finger, roughly a quarter of an inch from the fingertip. Press firmly so the spring-loaded lancet is discharged and the skin is punctured. Then set the lancet aside. Do not reuse the lancet.
As soon as blood appears, start the timer. Blot your finger with clean absorbent material every 30 seconds until the bleeding stops.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: As soon as the bleeding stops, stop the timer. Enter your bleeding time (to the nearest second) in Data Table 3.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Cover your fingertip with an adhesive bandage.
In Activity 4, you will study <button class='resource-text'>Figure 7</button> to identify the blood vessels.

Figure 7 shows a cross-section of two blood vessels viewed through a microscope. Examine the figure and determine whether each vessel is an or a . Enter your conclusions in Data Table 4, and for each vessel, list the main characteristics that led to your conclusions.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: Photo of two blood vessels labeled “A” and “B”; Vessel A has a relatively large lumen and thin walls compared to Vessel B.

text: Discard the alcohol preps in the garbage.
Using labware or a disposable glass or plastic container, mix about 1 part bleach with 9 parts tap water to produce an approximate 10% bleach solution.

pageData.text: Be sure to wear PPE when handling bleach, and do so only in a well-ventilated area.

text: Place the used lancets, tubes, absorbent material, and any clay that has come into contact with blood in the 10% bleach solution. Soak them for at least 1 hour.
Discard the absorbent material and clay in the garbage.
Place the lancets and tubes in a hard-sided container—such as a small cardboard box, plastic bottle, or disposable food container—before placing them in the garbage.
Dispose of solutions down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solutions.
Wash the test tube with soap and water. Let it air-dry, then return it to your lab kit.
Sanitize the work space.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.altText: completion

text: What was your hematocrit value?
Hematocrit values for healthy adults are approximately 40.7-50.3% for males and 36.1-44.3% for females. How does your hematocrit value compare?

pageData.text: Insert the photo of your hematocrit tube with the blood components separated.
Click on the browse button to upload the file

text: For an individual without anemia, the blood will typically sink to the bottom of the tube of copper sulfate solution by the end of the test. How does your test result compare?

pageData.text: Insert the photo of your copper sulfate test at 60 seconds.
Click on the browse button to upload the file

text: In the bleeding time test used in this investigation, a typical result for an adult individual with normal blood clotting is between about 1 and 9 minutes. What was your bleeding time, and how does it compare to the typical result?

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. To prepare, watch the blood smear demonstration video. In Activity 1, you will collect a blood sample in a hematocrit tube and calculate the hematocrit value. In Activity 2, you will collect a blood sample into a copper sulfate solution and conduct a copper sulfate test for hemoglobin. In Activity 3, you will stick your finger to draw blood and then conduct a bleeding time test. In Activity 4, you will distinguish between blood vessels in a micrograph.
pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. To prepare, watch the blood smear demonstration video. In Activity 1, you will collect a blood sample in a hematocrit tube and calculate the hematocrit value. In Activity 2, you will collect a blood sample into a copper sulfate solution and conduct a copper sulfate test for hemoglobin. In Activity 3, you will stick your finger to draw blood and then conduct a bleeding time test. In Activity 4, you will distinguish between blood vessels in a micrograph.

data.title: Albumin
data.content: The most abundant plasma protein and the most important plasma constituent for maintaining osmotic pressure

data.title: Alveoli
data.content: Tiny air sacs in the lungs

data.title: Aorta
data.content: The largest artery in the human body; it receives the systemic output of the heart

data.title: Arterioles
data.content: The smallest arteries; they convey blood into capillaries

data.title: Artery
data.content: Blood vessels that convey blood away from the heart

data.title: Basement membrane
data.content: A thin membranous layer of connective tissue that separates one layer of epithelial cells from the next

data.title: Basophil
data.content: A type of white blood cell with very dark bluish-purple granules; they contain histamine, an important chemical in the inflammatory response

data.title: Buffy coat
data.content: A yellowish-white layer that forms after the centrifugation of blood; in a centrifuged blood sample, it is located between the red blood cell and plasma layers

data.title: Capillaries
data.content: These blood vessels are the smallest, as well as have the thinnest walls

data.title: Capillary exchange
data.content: A process in which respiratory gases, nutrients, metabolic wastes, and other molecules are exchanged between the blood and the tissues

data.title: Continuous capillaries
data.content: The smallest blood vessels and the most common type to form capillary beds between arterioles and venules, as well as surround the alveoli

data.title: Copper sulfate test
data.content: A chemical test that identifies the presence of iron

data.title: Elastic arteries
data.content: Larger arteries that have a generous proportion of elastic fibers in their walls

data.title: Endothelium
data.content: A single layer of flattened cells that lines the cavities of the heart, blood and lymph vessels, and cavities of the body

data.title: Eosinophil
data.content: A type of white blood cell containing granules; it mainly protects the body from parasitic worms, but also plays an important role in allergic responses

data.title: Erythrocyte
data.content: A blood cell that does not have a nucleus; it contains hemoglobin that transports oxygen and carbon dioxide to and from the tissues; also called a red blood cell (RBC)

data.title: External elastic membrane
data.content: Located at the outer boundary of the tunica media of larger arteries; also called the external elastic lamina

data.title: Fenestrated capillaries
data.content: Found in the small intestine, kidneys, and endocrine glands such as the pancreas (these being organs where a great deal of molecular exchange occurs between blood and tissues); these capillaries have abundant pores (fenestrae or fenestrations) in their walls which make them highly permeable to molecules larger than the respiratory gases

data.title: Fibrinogen
data.content: A protein produced by the liver that promotes blood clotting

data.title: Formed element
data.content: One of the red blood cells, white blood cells, or blood platelets as contrasted with the fluid portion of the blood

data.title: Globulin
data.content: A type of protein that is soluble in dilute salt solutions; it makes up a large part of plasma

data.title: Hematocrit
data.content: The ratio of the volume of red blood cells to the total volume of blood

data.title: Hemoglobin
data.content: A protein found in red blood cells that carries oxygen; abbreviated Hb or Hgb

data.title: Hemostasis
data.content: A series of processes that stop blood flow

data.title: Hormone
data.content: A signaling molecule

data.title: Internal elastic membrane
data.content: A layer of elastic fibers at the outer boundary of the tunica intima; also called the internal elastic lamina

data.title: Iron-deficiency anemia
data.content: A condition when there is not enough iron that is needed to make hemoglobin

data.title: Leukocyte
data.content: An immune system cell; also called a white blood cell (WBC)

data.title: Lumen
data.content: Interior space

data.title: Lymphocyte
data.content: A type of leukocyte (white blood cell) comprising around 25% of the leukocyte population; it plays important roles in the immune response

data.title: Monocyte
data.content: A type of leukocyte (white blood cell) which, when stained, has blue-gray cytoplasm; it features U- or kidney-shaped nuclei and is the largest of all the leukocytes

data.title: Muscular arteries
data.content: Smaller arteries with less elastic fibers and a higher proportion of smooth muscle in their walls

data.title: Nervi vasorum
data.content: The nerves of some blood vessels

data.title: Neutrophil
data.content: The most abundant type of leukocyte (white blood cell); it is an essential part of the innate immune system, which protects the body from bacterial infections

data.title: Plasma
data.content: Colorless fluid part of blood

data.title: Pulmonary circulation
data.content: A type of blood circulation which carries deoxygenated blood away from the heart, through the capillaries in the lungs, and returns oxygenated blood to the heart

data.title: Simple squamous epithelium
data.content: A single layer of flattened cells

data.title: Systemic circulation
data.content: A type of blood circulation which carries oxygenated blood to, and returns deoxygenated blood from, the tissues of the body

data.title: Thrombocyte
data.content: A tiny cell fragment that, along with fibrin from plasma, helps stop bleeding when a blood vessel is injured; also called a platelet

data.title: Tunica externa
data.content: The outermost layer of a blood vessel wall; it is composed mainly of connective tissue, although the largest veins may also have smooth muscle tissue in this layer; also called the tunica adventitia

data.title: Tunica intima
data.content: Is the innermost layer of the vessel wall, located adjacent to the lumen; also called the tunica interna

data.title: Tunica media
data.content: The middle layer of a vessel wall; it is thicker in arteries compared to veins

data.title: Vasa vasorum
data.content: Small blood vessels that supply blood to or remove waste from the larger arteries and veins; their name means “vessels of the vessels”

data.title: Vasoconstriction
data.content: The narrowing of the lumen of the artery when the muscle contracts

data.title: Vasodilation
data.content: The increase in the lumen diameter that occurs when the smooth muscle relaxes

data.title: Veins
data.content: Blood vessels that convey blood toward the heart

data.title: Vena cava
data.content: The largest veins of the body

data.title: Venule
data.content: A very small vein that receives blood from capillary beds
